greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: x such that y^2 = C(x,0) + C(x,1) + C(x,2) + C(x,3) is soluble.
comment: n such that A000125(n) is a perfect square. - _Frank M Jackson_, Mar 13 2013
reference: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, Section D3.
link: Andrew Bremner, An equation of Mordell, Math. Comp., 29 (1975), pp. 925-928.
W. Ljunggren, A diophantine problem, J. London Math. Soc. (2), 3 (1971), pp. 385-391.
formula: x such that 6y^2 = (x + 1)(x^2 - x + 6) has solutions in integers.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
